top_comment.text:
*American Politics*
As an outside observer, the American political system interests me as 
America has a lot of economic sway globally .. so what happens in the US, 
impacts the rest of us in some way.

*What Amuses Me*
I have come to realise that the PR of the republican party is a seemingly 
never ending tirade of bad sound-bites and a failure to understand reality.

*So What's In This Clip?*
Dear.. America, especially those of a republican stance...

5:39 - *"why should the republican party care about a bunch of kids that 
don't know anything"*

Those 'kids' they are voters you know... and in only a few years those 
'kids' will be the people in office.

hypocrisy, idiocy and probably a few other words which end in 'y'

#billoreilly   #gopfail  ﻿
top_comment.author: Rich Peall

comments.text:
quote:
*"stopped listening to the very people they have taken an oath to 
represent"*

Now this I can relate to... when a democratic society refuses to bow to 
majority influence ( such as the recent finding that more than 50% of the 
US wants to legalise marijuana ) its clear to see the 'democratic process' 
simply doesn't exist.

There are strange nuances within the UK politics that have similar effect 
here...
comments.author: Rich Peall

comments.text:
What's sad is that the talking heads like Bill O'Reilly make the world tune 
out to the Republican voters.  We don't all think the way that the news 
pundits do.  Some of us just want the government to back off and stop 
trying to legislate every nuance of our lives.  

Our politicians seem to throw more poorly written legislation on top of the 
current poorly written legislation (on both sides of the political 
spectrum) and have stopped listening to the very people they have taken an 
oath to represent, all for the sake of getting money from the special 
interest groups who are taking money from the government in the form of 
"grants" and "public works" that are included in the poorly written 
legislation (often as clauses that have absolutely NOTHING to do with the 
original issue at hand).

Then you get the pundits like this one who twist and turn the issue to make 
"good" sound bites for their few minutes on the air in the hopes of 
influencing more sponsors to pay for advertising and line their pockets.  

Meanwhile the average American citizen who is happy to pay what they owe 
for taxes and wants to just live their lives with the hope of leaving 
something better for their children are getting run over by the political 
train and those who speak against whatever legislation is being proposed 
are labeled as people who either don't want to help their fellow citizens 
or who are lazy-do-nothings who want to suck off the government teat rather 
than better themselves (both of which are not true...).  

It really is a sad state of affairs for us in the US, too.  For what it's 
worth, I wish that people like Glen Beck and Bill O'Reilly would lose all 
of their sponsors and go off the air.  They aren't helping anyone.
comments.author: Polly Merkner

comments.text: http://www.happletea.com/2009/07/01/same-as-it-ever-was/
comments.author: Amber Petchey

top_comment.text:
This is what I don't understand about American politics: Black people vote 
democrat. Gays vote democrat. Hispanics vote democrat. Young people vote 
democrat. Women vote democrat to a greater extent than they vote 
Republican. All these huge groups of people all generally vote democrat. So 
why is it that every election is quite close? You would think the democrats 
got 70% of the votes at least with that kind of groups behind them...but 
it's always more or less 50-50. ﻿
top_comment.author: Mike Vizioz

comments.text:
+Mike Vizioz Gerrymandering (most recently in 2010) is also a big 
consideration. For example, Democratic politicians received more votes than 
Republicans, but obviously lost a large number of seats in 2014. And don't 
forget that Al Gore won the popular vote (as well as the electoral vote if 
the recount had been done, but that's another story) despite the fact that 
Bush was given the presidency.
comments.author: Sheldon T Dunn Jr

i see the public education system did you wonders
comments.author: Tenza Zangetsu

comments.text:
+Tenza Zangetsu you couldn't debunk his argument so you nit pick over 
semantics; "you mean civil rights"...weak dude. You just expressed that 
"they" (homosexuals) shouldn't be counted as a group. You obviously don't 
care about their civil rights wise guy.

But people are complex, I'm black and gay. I shy away from people who 
diminish both of these identities by being in favor of policies that go 
against both my interests. If I can't or shouldn't be categorized ie 
discriminated against based on my sexuality Indiana apparently didn't get 
the memo. Just admit you don't recognize LGBTQ people's humanity because of 
your own personal bias and stop trying to rationalize your bigotry in order 
to make yourself feel better.
comments.author: Lamar Cox

comments.text:
+Mike Vizioz
you mean civil rights? gay rights sounds ignorant.
comments.author: Tenza Zangetsu

comments.text:
+Tenza Zangetsu Because people vote in their own interests. Of course 
sexuality is a factor when a person decides to vote. If one party is intent 
on denying homosexuals their rights and the other party is intent on giving 
them their rights, homosexuals WILL vote for the party that gives them 
basic human rights.
comments.author: Mike Vizioz

comments.text:

comments.author: Tenza Zangetsu

comments.text:
+Tenza Zangetsu When they are using statistics they can use several 
different ways to categorize people. You are proposing a world in which 
humanity can ONLY be categorized into their ethnicities. But it can only be 
categorized into sexuality, religious afffiliation, age, gender etc. Why is 
it only sexuality that causes a hang-up in you? Why have you not complained 
about me categorizing young people into one group? Yes, gays cannot be a 
seperate group when people are being categorized by their ethnicity. A gay 
hispanic will still belong to the hispanic group. Not if if categorize by 
sexuality though because it will then be the person's ethnicity that 
doesn't matter.

I shouldn't have to explain this. This is really basic stuff.
comments.author: Mike Vizioz

comments.text:
+Mike Vizioz
doesn't make sense to label gays as a group because when they start using 
statistics of what group of people vote, talking blacks, whites, hispanics, 
there could be a gay hispanic voter. so does that mean the gay hispanic 
person gets counted for 2 groups of voters? it's stupid when you think 
about it, or do you just look at and say oh that's how it is and not think 
about....

comments.text:

comments.author: Vito Leonardo

top_comment.text:
I am a Registered Republican at in my mid twenties, and I believe that the 
whole young voter thing is damaging this nation, by far we don't pay 
attention to what we vote for and fall on propaganda that can be condensed 
into a 5-10 minute video (much like this one) either due to time 
constraints or what have you. its the reason we have Obama in power... and 
are where we are as a nation.﻿
top_comment.author: Jeremy Huijon

comments.text:
The reason why we have Obama and perhaps more future Democratic Presidents 
is because your party is closed minded and instead of moving forward, you 
want to move backwards. The Tea Party and a bunch of birthers have taken 
over your party and it is these racists from both groups that are making 
the GOP unattractive to not only young voters, but women voters, Hispanic 
voters, black voters, gay voters, and other minority voters. Most of the 
young voters that I have been talking to (I am in my mid-50s) know what 
they want to vote for. They want things such as corporations having to pay 
their share of taxes, they want lower interest rates on college loans, they 
want more employment opportunities, and so on. During the 2012 election, 
many of these young folks and I am including those who were not yet old 
enough to vote said something to me that was quite telling: They felt that 
the statements about rape in which GOP Senate Candidates like Todd Akin and 
Richard Mourdock made were quite disturbing to them and they were quite 
thankful that the citizens in the states that they are from (Missouri and 
Indiana respectively and states Mitt Romney won) did not allow them into 
the US Senate because they are real misogynists. As for Bill O'Reilly not 
listening to these youngsters on his show and treating them as individuals 
who know nothing, they may just say the hell with the GOP and just either 
not vote or vote Democrat. O'Reilly has the same mentality as most of the 
old guys in the GOP that do not want change!
comments.author: 2468allan

comments.text:
If people watch this video most times they are watching the channel, 
nothing was out of context so what propaganda? You do know the only 
demographic Obama lost in was older white men right?  The GOP lost in all 
minorities, younger, and women, go to Breitbart and read the article about 
millennials, the entire article and comments are nothing but insults 
calling an entire generation stupid and lazy, and then shock they turn from 
the GOP.
